section.para: Use to open a new search window and enter the word or phrase you wish to search for in the search field.
You can have several search windows opened at the same time. Hit CSF to reuse the most recent search window.
Alternatively, select a word or phrase in the , , or pane and use . The selection is automatically entered in the search field.
Click the drop-down arrow of the Search for: field to access the last ten searches.
Click on Search or hit Enter when the search field is selected to start the search.
Matches will be displayed in bold blue characters.
The search window has its own menus:

listitem.para: File > Search for Selection (CF): the current selection is inserted in the search field.
File > Close (CW): close the search window.
Edit > Insert Source (CSI): insert the content of the current source segment.
Edit > Replace with Source (CSR): replace the contents of the search field with those of the current source segment.
Edit > Create Glossary Entry (CSG): add a new glossary item. See for details.
Edit > Reset Options: reset the search window options.

section.title: Search type
section.para: Use the radio buttons to select the type of search.
The following search types are available:

listitem.para: Search for the string exactly as entered in the search field.
It is equivalent to a web search enclosed in quotation marks.
Search for segments containing each of the search terms separated by a space.
It is equivalent to a web search without quotation marks.

note.para: The * and ? characters can be used in both exact and keyword searches:

listitem.para: * matches zero or more characters, from the current position up to the end of a word.
The search term run*, for example, matches run, runs and running.
? matches any single character.
For instance, run? matches runs, as well as the runn portion of running or runner.
Treat the search string as a regular expression.
Regular expressions are a very powerful way to search for general or complex patterns rather than exact strings. See the appendix for details.

warning.para: The * and ? characters have a special meaning in regular expressions. Therefore, the wild card searches described above only apply to exact and keyword searches.

listitem.para: Only returns results with the same letter case as the search terms.
Space characters in search terms will match both a normal space and a non-breaking space (\u00A) character.
Search in the source segments.
Search in the target segments.
Search in notes attached to segments.
Search in comments attached to segments.
Search in both translated and untranslated segments.
Search only in translated segments.
Search only in untranslated segments.
Every segment is displayed individually, even if it is a repetition found in either the same document or a different document in the project.
The name of the file where the segment is found is displayed above each result.
Search in the various bilingual resources of the project.
Select the scope of the search:
Include the project memory ().
Include the translation memories located in the folder.
Include the glossaries located in the folder.
Search in reference files not included in the project resources.
OmegaT can conduct searches in any file that it can read as source file. See the chapter for details.
TMX files are excluded from file searches since OmegaT does not recognize them as a source file format despite supporting them as translation memories.
Select additional criteria such as the person who authored or changed the translation, the date and time of translation (modification), or whether to exclude orphan segments.
Returns results that match both the full- and half-width forms (CJK characters) of the characters in the search terms.
Sets the maximum number of matches displayed in the search result area.
Use the Hide Advanced Options button to stop showing the advanced options.

section.title: Results display
section.para: Matches are displayed in their order of appearance in the project. For translated segments, the original text is displayed above the translated text. Only the source text is displayed for untranslated segments.
Double-click on a segment to open it in the pane.
You can also use the following shortcuts in the search results:

listitem.para: Move to the next segment
Move to the preceding segment
Jump to the current segment in the editor.

varlistentry.term: Back to the initial segment on close

listitem.para: When you close the search windows, the pane automatically goes back to the segment that it displayed before the search was started

section.title: Filter
section.para: Click on the Filter button to show only the matching search result segments in the pane. To remove the filter, click on the Remove Filter button at the top of the pane, or reload the project.
